segments.question: And th Œ so if you were alone, you had far less chance.
segments.answer: Exactly. Because family held together, helped to stay Œ you know, had your mind set out to s Œ on survival.

segments.question: So you went through the winter of 1940, the summer of 1940 and the winter of 1941. And, was that second winter pretty similar to the first?
segments.answer: Well, winter itself was similar, but as far as we were concerned, we were in much worse shape, physically.

segments.question: Okay, ec Œ describe it.
segments.answer: Mainly Œ

segments.question: Yeah. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 95
segments.answer: Œ mainly physically. We were Œ we were starving, you know, eating just bread, and very little of it, doesn™t bi-build up any strength, any Œ you Œ you are hungry most of the time.

segments.question: So you were weaker with Œ
segments.answer: You were weaker Œ weaker physically , and sometime, like I said before, people got to the point where they were giving up.

segments.question: So did they commit suicide?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: They just died.
segments.answer: They didn™t have to, they didn™t have to, they just laid down and died. And it happened, a lot of people happen ed, and Œ to a lot of people.

segments.question: Were there any other transports that came after you?
segments.answer: No, no. No more people. We™re di Œ we™re Œ a Œ eventually, we know now that there were other transports, but at that tim e, at our place, we didn™t have a idea.

segments.question: Okay, you would have been the only ones.
segments.answer: We were Œ we were getting some mail from Poland, but whenever people tried to tell us something, it was cut out by censo rship. We would get the letters with the parts of it cut out.

segments.question: I see. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 96
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: I see. So the second winter was a lot harder than the first one?
segments.answer: Positively, positively, positively. Our clothes were already in shreds, and we were very, very bad shape physically. Wit Œ what™s happened, second summer, the authorities told us that we can try to have a gardens.

segments.question: Oh, you were allowed to have ga Œ
segments.answer: We were allowed to Œ to have a garden s. So we Œ they divided some of the open area in the camp into plots, and it Œ we drew lots, and it just happ ened that we Œ our part Œ our lot was very far in the Œ practically in the woods. What turned out that nobody drew a lot which was right in front of our barrack. So my mother went to the Œ the ca Œ ca Œ our commander, and ask hi m if she could cha Œ trade the Œ the Œ and she did. So we had a Œ about, I would say 50 by 50 feet plot of land that we could Œ we could Œ

segments.question: Plant.
segments.answer: Œ plant. It just happened, this is a st ory in itself. Second summer, my mother and I, we went to the village, which is located about 28 kilometers, to trade, I think it was my father™s jacket or something, for some 60 or 80 pounds of potatoes. The problem was that we™d had no means of br inging those potatoes to the camp. So we told the Russians people to keep it for us, and we will come back for it in the winter. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 97It just again happened that my mother was sick. She lifted something heavy while she was working in the woods, and hurt he r back, she couldn™t get up. She was in bed. And th Œ we were really starving. We had a family get together, and decided that we have t Œ my brother, who was that time just eight years old Œ no, I™m sorry, he was practically nine already. No, he was eight years old. And I was practically 13 Œ no, I was 13 years old. So, that were two of us, right in the middle of winter, we have to go and get those potatoes. Twen ty-eight kilometers in the winter, 30 below zero.

segments.question: Oh my gosh.
segments.answer: I, previous summer, I work Œ I made a sled, I built a s Œ myself a sled. We were gonna use that sled to bring those potatoes. So, my mother gave me and my brother slice of bread. That had to last us two days. And early in the morning we marched with dragging that sled. We went to, a 13 a nd a eight, practically nine year old boys, 28 kilometers to bring the 60 or 80 pounds of potatoes.

segments.question: Potatoes. And you did?
segments.answer: We walked all day. When I close my eyes now, I still see when we got out of the woods, there was a small hill, and on top of the hill there were some hats Œ hats, with the chimneys, and the smoke coming from the chi Œ it looked like picture from heaven, after walking all day. I found the hats, with my Œ where the potatoes were. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 98We got in hat Œ the room was full of people. Turned out th ere were people that were going, men mostly, that were going to go to our camp with horses and Œ to help working in the woods, in the logging. I still remember the smell of the sweat, bodies, and the cigars, or smo Œ I mean, s Œ pipes and smoking. We slept all on the grou Œ on the floor. Woke up in next morning about five, six o™clock in the morning. I went outside. Turned out during the night, about 12 inches of snow fell.

segments.question: Oh my goodness. You were saved. You were saved, cause it could have fallen on you.
segments.answer: But this was Œ going thro ugh the virgin forest was ju st a, you know, path cut out through the Œ through the woods. I had the idea. I started going to every man, asking if they will allow us to tie our sled to their horse Œ horse drawn sled, you know, to help us.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: None of them would allow it.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Finally, there was a woman with a young girl, most likely my age. And I ask her. First she refuse, and then she change her mind. She says, all right, you can do it on one condition, that you lead my horse. Of course, I agreed to it. So we put our bag of potatoes on the sled, covered it with the blanket and some straw. My son Œ my Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 99brother would sit on it, and the Œ the sled wa s full of about five feet high with hay for the horses that would be fed on the Œ in our camp. And the two women climbed on the top of that sled hay, and I would lead it. We were about the last ones of the whole caravan of those sleds. E-Everything was fine, until we got to about the middle of the distance to our camp. There was a steep hill, downwards went the road, and on the bottom there was a stream, which of course was frozen solid now. And there the pass Œ the road turned left. Well, we were coming down th-the sleds that went ahead of us, cleaned the road pr etty well, so when we were coming, it was pretty slick going. I kept holding the horse as much as I could, but the Œ gradually horse start to galloping, faster and faster. Finally I couldn™t keep up with him, so I let go. The sled with the Œ went all the way down to the hill, and made the turn. As it made the turn to the left, it slid sideways, hit the embankment of snow, and the two women were catapult out of the top of th e sled, into the big pile of snow. All I could see is two pair of legs sticking out. Of course, my brother turn over too.

segments.question: What happened to the potatoes?
segments.answer: Well, they were Œ they were turned over too, into the snow. It took us about half an hour to straighten out the sled, and put back the potatoes on Œ on the sled [indecipherable] with my little sled, my brother on it. By the end of the day, we were at our camp. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 100

segments.question: Oh my goodness.
segments.answer: Next day I was walking, and I seen that woman splitting logs for her fireplace. She wasn™t much good at it, but I was. For next hour or so I split all the wood that she had. That was my thank you to her fo r being so good and help us, because I don™t know how we would have made it back that night, to the camp. So she was good to me, and I repaid it by Œ

segments.question: Splitting her logs.
segments.answer: Œ splitting her woods for her.

segments.question: Amazing.
segments.answer: Amazing.

segments.question: Amazing.
segments.answer: And when I think about it now, my brother wasn™t even nine years old.

segments.question: And the potatoes, did they help?
segments.answer: Oh, God. Wa Œ there were Œ there were Œ that Œ I don™t remember how long ago we went to sleep with our bellies full. The potatoes tasted better than any before and any time after, when they did. And for next month or so, and when Œ when we got the plot of land, when my mother would peel the potatoes, her Œ she Œ when there was a eye, with the possibility of growing, she would make a big, deep cut and save Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 101it. So we planted those pieces, and next year we had a Œ some Œ our own fresh potatoes growing.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: That was part of the good story.

segments.question: It is. It is, but what a difficult Œ what a difficult thing to do. And for little boys, I mean, as you were starting to tell this, I wa s thinking, my goodness, those potatoes will freeze on that Œ on that journey.
segments.answer: Well, it was like I said, we covered with Œ with the straw, with the blanket, and my brother was sitting on Œ

segments.question: Sitting on top of it, like a chicken on some eggs.
segments.answer: Exactly, yes.

segments.question: So, by this time, let™s say, the second winter goes by, and that™s the winter of 1941, and then the summer is when you plant, or Œ
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Œ yes, you plant those Œ
segments.answer: Yes, yes, yes.

segments.question: Now, in June 1941 is when Germany attacked the Soviet Union. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 102
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Did your lives change after that?
segments.answer: Well, the irony of it, that we, that year we got what Russians call the amnesty. To have Œ to have am nesty, you have to commit something, right?

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Well, I don™t know what we committed.

segments.question: But you got amnesty anyway.
segments.answer: But we got amnesty anyway. And who do we thank for that?

segments.question: Who?
segments.answer: Hitler. So, is it the irony that we have Hitler to thank for our freedom. Now, the way it worked, Russians at that time, when Germany attacked Russia, were in such a bad shape, within a few months, Germany was right into the Russian territory. They went through the eastern Poland , into German authority. Russians were looking for help, for allies. At that time, Russia held about a quarter of a million Polish soldiers in it Œ prison of war camp s. Russians wanted to use those men to defend Russia . They tr Œ to Œ got in touch with Polish government in exile in ri Œ in London, to form Polish army in Russia. They agreed Œ Polish government agreed on one condition. That they will release rest of the people, too. That included us. So that™s what the amnesty was about. And we were officially told by Œ by officials. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 103

segments.question: By the commandant, or Œ
segments.answer: By the commandant.

segments.question: Not the KGB man.
segments.answer: No, no, commandant, that we are free peopl e. We were given passes, legi Œ le Œ legitimacy.

segments.question: Legitimization.
segments.answer: That™s right. That we could travel in Russia, that we can get supply of bread whenever w Œ it was available. But we were Œ main thing, we were free to leave the camp.

segments.question: And when did this Œ when did this come? When did this happen?
segments.answer: This was fall of ™41.

segments.question: So, it was several months after Germany attacked.
segments.answer: That™s right.

segments.question: So in the fall of ™41, when you finally have some potatoes of your own.
segments.answer: That™s right. That™s true, that™s very true.

segments.question: Your ha Œ you™re told that you are free to go.
segments.answer: We were free to go, but go fra Œ where?

segments.question: Yeah. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 104
segments.answer: We were told that there™s a Polish army being organized in the southern Russia , in the Œ in the Kazakhstan , in the Uzbekistan . We were told that there™s Œ that™s where the Polish army is being organized. But how do we get there? This is 3,000 kilometers from where we are. Now, it was due south wi Œ by this time the German armies were already approaching Moscow, so there was no way we could go straight south. A lot of people were he sitating, didn™t want to leave the camp because after all, there was some security here, and if we leave camp, who Œ then what? My mother was a different Œ of different opinion. She says she won™t stay here any more, we have to leave. And sure enough, we Œ my sister went to a Œ the village, which was about 20 some mi Œ kilometers to, from Œ from our camp, and next thing we know, she came back couple days later with the horse-drawn sled, with the farmer, and that we can leave the camp Œ

segments.question: With him?
segments.answer: Œ and he will take us to the Œ that village, and from there there was only few kilometers to the railroad station Œ railroad that was being built. It Œ it wasn™t built yet, they were just building the railroad. So we packed whatever we still had, things, and traveled over for a day and a half, we traveled to that village.

segments.question: So you left fairly soon afterwards?
segments.answer: We Œ we left, it was Œ was winter of ™42. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 105

segments.question: Two.
segments.answer: I think it was January Œ January somethi ng, beginning of Janua ry, I think we left the camp. We got to that town, that village, and it turned out it was about 10 kilometers to the railroad sta Œ railroad. Not station, but railroad. Again, my mother bribed some of the people ove r there with some tobacco. And they told us that we can load in, into the Œ get into one of the freight cars that was bringing supplies, railroad supplies, and we traveled about three days. They closed the doors completely because they didn™t want anybody know what we Œ we were in the car. It was freezing. We had to walk most of the time to Œ to Œ not to freeze.

segments.question: To keep warm.
segments.answer: To keep warm. Finally we got to the town that we were originally dropped off Œ

segments.question: Oh, where you had walked Œ
segments.answer: Œ where we were brought.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: We got Œ turns out there were thousand people just like us out there, from different camps all over ye Œ Russia, that part of Russia. And within a few days the conditions were terrible, unbelievably terrible.

segments.question: Were you all at the railroad station? Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 106
segments.answer: The railroad station. Finally is Œ we Œ somehow we found out that there was a train preparing to go south, which had some of those cars prepared for traveling, for deporting [indecipherable] people. So we got on the train.

segments.question: And was it also like freight trains, or was Œ
segments.answer: It wa Œ well, there were some empty cars, but just about everybody that was on that station, got on that train. Of course Polish people. Three months we traveled on that train.

segments.question: Oh my gosh.
segments.answer: Three months we traveled on that train. We lost more people on that train than in the camp.

segments.question: Oh my gosh.
segments.answer: The worst Œ the worst was when somebo dy got lost from the train, we never Œ we never found them. It just happened that my mother got lost. What would happen, we would get to the station, and people, some people from each car would run to the center of the town to see if they could buy, steal or whatever some food. And sometime when they were there, the train would go Œ would start going, and leave them behind. And like I said, most of the time, when train would leave those people, we never seen them again.

segments.question: So what happened with your mother? Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 107
segments.answer: My mother was one of the people that went to get some food. In the meantime, they took our train and just moved it to different siding. When my mother came back to the original spot, who Œ the Œ whoe ver was in charge told her that our train left. She jumped on the next train and traveled for about three days, without sign of our train. So she decided that she must ha ve missed it, and she started coming back. And would you know, she found us. Not on ly did she found us, but she brought about two loaves of bread with her.

segments.question: What a miracle.
segments.answer: Was a miracle. We were desperate. We were four children, and their grandma.

segments.question: Oh my.
segments.answer: Four children and their grandma.

segments.question: Oh my goodness.
segments.answer: My dear, we were creatures from hell. Dirty. All through those three months, we never change clothes, we never washed . There was enough water for drinking, never mind washing or Œ or Œ our clothe s or washing yourself. Can you imagine the stink? Forty people in the car. We were in one of the towns, I don™t remember the name now, big town. And all of a sudden, all through the train went the news that on a different siding, there™s a train just like ours, and in that train, there™s a priest that™s gonna say a mass. Believe me, everyb ody, whoever could stand on their feet, Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 108we run to that siding, and sure enough, ther e was in one of the cars, the gate Œ door was open, there was a table, and a young priest was saying a mass. He was in a shreds of clothes just like we were. Dirty, filthy, but you could tell he was a God™s man. We were kneeling on the snow, we were praying. We were singing Polish songs. At the end of it we usually sing a song which says, God, let us Œ give us Œ give us a chance to get to freedom, get to pola Œ get back to Poland, to our cri Œ our country.

segments.question: I can™t imagine what that scene must have been like.
segments.answer: It gaved us spirit. It gave us a reason to live again. Believe me, it was one of the miracles that makes human do things that sometime you don™t think you can do it. Well, our luck was with us anyway. We got through Kazakhstan Œ just one Œ I wrote it in my life story. When we were going through Kazakhstan , the Œ the scenery was totally flat steppe.

segments.question: The steppes.
segments.answer: Steppes, yes. And I was looking through that small window, and what do I see? Right along the railroad tracks, on the snow, there™s a fox, a red fox. Was running parallel to a train, but at least he knew Œ you could tell he kne w exactly where he was going, and we didn™t have the s lightest idea where we were going.

segments.question: Oh my. Yeah. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 109
segments.answer: It™s stuck in my mind now. Anyway, finally we got to the end Œ to bekist Œ paki Œ not Pakistan, it was Bekistan(ph). And there they told us to unload at one of the stations, I don™t remember now which one.

segments.question: Was it Tashkent?
segments.answer: No, no, it wasn™t Tashkent. But not far from it. And we Œ there were Œ they put is in the kolkhoz . You know what kolkhoz is?

segments.question: Explain, please.
segments.answer: Kolkhoz is a government farm.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Where people don™t own anything, they ju st work for a government farm. A farm was Œ they were raising cotton. This is main there, that™s what they grow in that part of Uzbekistan . Well, they assign us to the Uzbek family. They gave us a little room with a dirt floor, and my mother and my young Œ my older sister worked in the fields, and I worked in the smith shop.

segments.question: Was this Polish authorities, or Russian authorities?
segments.answer: Russian authorities. But turned out that there were already some Polish authorities in the area, too. Finally we contacted them. And they kept us Œ kept telling us to sit tight, they™ll notify us where and when we have to go. We spend, I don™t know, about four months up there, and working pretty hard. Finally, my Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 110mother again, she has enough. With the last thing that she still had Œ there were two more Polish families in the area. They bribed drivers that were going Œ what we heard was town about hundred kilometers from where we were at, where there was already Polish army post. So , one day we loaded up on the Œ on the truck, open truck, and for next 24 hours Œ it took th em 24 hours to drive us that hundred kilometers. Every 20 some kilometers, they had to change the tires on the truck.

segments.question: Really? It was that bad.
segments.answer: That good. Finally, at night, we arrive d on that station, where we™re su Œ we were told that there™s a Polish outpost. Sure enough, we unloade d at night, and we were sit Œ by this time it was nice and warm up there. This is south of Russia. So, I think it was some time in March or April already, and we were sitting against the wall on the Œ on the station. It started getting light, and we could hear men™s walk is with the military boots on the Œ on the platform. My mother jumped up and there was a Œ one sergeant and two soldiers comi ng towards us. My moth er looked at him and run to him and started hugging him. He was a policeman from the Vorudek (ph).

segments.question: No kidding.
segments.answer: He was Œ the man was a Œ the sergeant was a policeman from the Vorudek (ph), that knew my parents very well. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 111

segments.question: Oh my goodness.
segments.answer: From that time on our lives changed. Tu rned out that a quartermaster of the 22 nd regiment, that was stationed in the place Œ place was called Karmana . And he was a buddy of my father™s. Quartermaster. He made my mother seamstress, she Œ she put Œ he put her to work. My older sister wer Œ couldn™t go anywhere, because she suffered Œ she infect Œ got infected with typhoid. But my younger sister was Œ joined the girls Œ yo-young girls™ camp. My brother and I, we went to the boys™ camp. And also turned out Œ turned out that one day, while I was in the camp, I was told that I have to report to the colonel that was in charge of 22nd regiment. I got scared. I didn™t do anything wrong, I Œ I sa luted everybody, and here I am told to report Œ

segments.question: Report.
segments.answer: Œ to the colonel, of Œ of all the people. Turned out he knew my father when they were young officers in the 1920. When he seen my name, he wanted to know if we know what happened to father. So that™s what he wanted me to report to him. But like I said, from that time on, our lives changed. Mother was secure, thi Œ we were secured.

segments.question: Did you get more food? Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 112
segments.answer: Oh God. First time I was taken to the military mess, they get me vast pool of rice and r Œ and raisins. I ate about quarter of it and I couldn™t eat no more. I could not. I sat there and I cried because I can™t Œ couldn™t swallow any more.

segments.question: You were full?
segments.answer: I guess my stomach shrunk so that it Œ there was no room for it already. But eventually, that went by. On the middle of August, 1942, we were put on the train from the Karmana, from the camp, and taken to the port on the Caspian Sea.

segments.question: What was the name of the port?
segments.answer: Krasnovodsk .

segments.question: Krasnovodsk , okay.
segments.answer: Krasnovodsk . We were put on the Russian ship. They Œ we were loaded, standing room only, practically.

segments.question: Like sardines, huh?
segments.answer: Like sardines. My brother was on that sh ip, too. He was very sick. He wa Œ he had dysentery, which sometime it can kill you.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But he survived.

segments.question: So it was your m Œ you, your mother, your sisters. Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 113
segments.answer: Well, n Œ on the camp, there was j Œ on that ship there was just two of us. My mother stayed behind with my grandmothe r and two sisters. They left about two weeks later. We arrived in [indecipherable] at that time was Persia, now it™s Iran. Port of Baklevy (ph).

segments.question: Baklevy(ph), mm-hm.
segments.answer: Baklevy(ph), we arrived there. Finally, we were free. We could really say we were free.

segments.question: What if Œ what kind of a feeling was it?
segments.answer: It™s like a Œ when the weight is dropped off your shoulders. That you could speak freely without, you know, looking if someone is watching you. That you™re your own master, you™re Œ you™re Œ you™re free. I was 14 years old. My Œ at that time, I was still in Russia, I was assigned to the military band, and I was learning how to play clarinet and violin. Clarinet, I was doing fine. Violin, I wasn™t. But our main job was drumming. When the orchestra wa s marching, we were, the eight of us, lined up in the front, drummers. And also, whenever we had to Œ other parades, we would take part of it. With that orchestra, I got out Œ I got out of Russia, and I got to Œ we got Œ from Persia we got to Camp Khanaqin in Iraq.

segments.question: So you were Œ your brother was with you the whole time? Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 114
segments.answer: He wasn™t with me, but in Œ with the s Œ in the same regiment that we were attached to. So I seen him when got to Iraq, and later we missed Œ we lost contact for a while. And then in January 1943, we got orders to leave Iraq and go to Palestine, to join Polish military schools. There were so many of young boys that was rescued from Russia , from all different camps. They formed schools, from grade school that my Œ my brother was at Œ finally went through. I went through a high school already, to the Polish cadet school, which was preparing young men to be officers in the Polish army.

segments.question: And you were how old at this po Œ
segments.answer: I was 14 years old.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: I Œ when I Œ when I got to the camp in Palestine, the camp™s name was Kastinna(ph). It was in the southern part of Palestine, not far from, n-now it™s called Gaza Strip .

segments.question: Ah, not far from there.
segments.answer: Not far from there. I stayed there til 1945. I finished, or practically finished my high school up there. And then Œ

segments.question: Is that the tie from the cadet school? Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 115
segments.answer: Yes, that™s Œ that™s the tie that you™re presents by cadet school. I also in Œ I have a blazer with my as Œ as Œ s-sign over here on the chest, and few of the other der Œ decorations. We belong to a Œ to a Œ there was a Polish division, third Carpathian division that fought under General Anders, fought Germans in Italy, Monte Cassino and the other places. And that division took care of our school. In turn, when our boys and the bow Œ our boys that turn 18, which was military age, they would be assigned to that division.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Few of my friends that just happened that they were older than I was, their crosses are up there.

segments.question: In Monte Cassino ?
segments.answer: In Monte Cassino , yes. For Œ few of my very close friends.

segments.question: So they didn™t make it.
segments.answer: Well, they Œ they died up there, fighting for Poland . I stayed in Palestine until May ™45. May ™45, I left there, traveled through the Mediterranean Sea. I volunteer for a Polish merchant marine navigational officers™ school in England .

segments.question: Well, did you find Œ did the end of the war Œ were you still in Palestine?
segments.answer: I was still in Palestine.

segments.question: So tell Œ do you remember when you hear Œ heard the war is over? Interview with Adam Szymel January 25, 2015 116
segments.answer: Oh God, do we remember ? You couldn™t Œ it was so sad. Every Friday my school would Œ all the companies would marc h, and we were on the parade grounds, and the officer would be reading na mes of our friends that were in Italy fighting, si Œ ones that were wounded, and ones that were killed. It was a very sad, sad Œ and that meant that the war will end, and that be the end of it, which is a total, total relief. Total. Specially fact that we were the winners, too.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: We Œ we survived. In the meantime, my mother Œ
